etymologies: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘usurp an office or right’; originally as entrude): from Latin intrudere, from in- ‘into’ + trudere ‘to thrust’

definitions: put oneself deliberately into a place or situation where one is unwelcome or uninvited

examples.text: he had no right to intrude into their lives
she felt awkward at intruding on private grief

shortDefinitions: put oneself somewhere where one is unwelcome

definitions: enter with disruptive or adverse effect

examples.text: politics quickly intrude into the booklet

definitions: introduce into a situation with disruptive or adverse effect

examples.text: to intrude political criteria into military decisions risks reducing efficiency

shortDefinitions: introduce into situation with disruptive effect

definitions: (of igneous rock) be forced or thrust into (a preexisting formation)

examples.text: the granite may have intruded these rock layers

shortDefinitions: (of igneous rock) be forced into pre-existing formation

definitions: force or thrust (igneous rock) into a preexisting formation.
shortDefinitions: force igneous rock to do this
